definition: Pre-engagement evaluation of third-party service providers to determine risk level and GLBA compliance capability. Includes vendor questionnaire
organization_owner: and risk-based tiering. Documented and retained per examination requirements.
version: Per GLBA Safeguards Rule and Interagency Guidance on Third-Party Relationships, institutions must implement policies and procedures to ensure third-party service providers with access to customer information maintain safeguards and comply with GLBA requirements. Vendor assessment is foundational control; must occur before engagement; risk assessment determines vendor tier and ongoing oversight requirements. Assessment components: vendor identification and questionnaire; security questionnaire covering encryption, access controls, incident response; financial stability review; background checks; regulatory examination history; customer references. Vendor questionnaire addresses: GLBA awareness; data handling procedures; information security program; access controls; encryption practices; backup and recovery; incident response plan; business continuity; employee training; third-party sub-vendor management; audit procedures; compliance history. Risk assessment determines vendor tier: Tier 1 (Low): limited customer data access, non-sensitive data, secure environment, strong controls; Tier 2 (Medium): moderate data access, some sensitive data, standard controls; Tier 3 (High): extensive customer data access, highly sensitive data, critical functions, extensive oversight required; Tier 4 (Critical): essential vendor, critical functions, third-party data handling, heightened oversight. Assessment documentation includes: vendor name, address, contact information; services provided; customer data access; risk assessment score; tier assignment; contract recommendations; monitoring plan. Retention: retain assessment documentation; maintain updated records; reassess every 2-3 years; update for significant changes.
status: All institutions using third-party service providers; any vendor with access to customer information; applies to all institution sizes; mandatory for compliance; includes cloud service providers, IT vendors, payroll processors, backup vendors, disaster recovery, business intelligence, marketing service providers

column13: Vendor Assessment Process: Step 1 - Vendor Identification: identify need for vendor; determine services required; customer data scope; Step 2 - Preliminary Screening: check regulatory history; financial stability; industry reputation; references. Step 3 - Security Questionnaire: detailed questionnaire on information security program; encryption standards; access controls; multi-factor authentication; vulnerability management; incident response; business continuity; employee training; third-party management; audit procedures; certifications held (ISO 27001, SOC 2, etc.). Step 4 - On-Site Assessment (if applicable): for high-risk or critical vendors; review security controls; interview key personnel; test access controls; assess environment. Step 5 - Risk Assessment: evaluate inherent risk (data sensitivity, access scope, criticality); assess control strength; determine risk tier; document scoring. Step 6 - Contract Negotiation: include GLBA compliance requirements; data handling procedures; information security standards; incident notification requirements; termination and data return procedures; audit rights; indemnification; insurance requirements; liability limits. Step 7 - Documentation and Approval: document assessment; obtain approvals (Compliance, Risk, Legal); store in vendor management system; communicate tier and requirements to vendor. Vendor Assessment Factors: Data Sensitivity: access to SSN highest risk; financial account numbers high risk; payment card data high risk; health information sensitive; non-sensitive data lowest risk. Scope of Data Access: number of customer records accessed; portion of customer base affected; entire database versus subset. Criticality to Operations: essential vendor critical functions (disaster recovery, business continuity); high-priority vendor important but replaceable; low-priority vendor non-critical. Vendor Size and Stability: large established vendor lower risk; small vendor or startup higher risk; financial stability assessment important; multi-year financial statements review. Security Maturity: comprehensive information security program lower risk; limited or no program higher risk; certifications (SOC 2, ISO 27001) indicate maturity; compliance with standards. Regulatory Status: vendor subject to regulation (bank, broker) lower risk; unregulated vendor higher risk; prior enforcement actions indicate concern; regulatory examination history relevant. Prior Breach History: no prior breaches preferred; history of breaches indicates higher risk; incidents in similar environments concerning; vendor response to breach important. Customer References: check references from other financial institutions; inquire about reliability, performance, security practices; incident history with other customers. Sub-Vendor Management: vendor's management of their own vendors important; understanding of their sub-vendors required; ensuring sub-vendor compliance. Vendor Questionnaire Components: Company Information section: vendor name, address, contact; years in business; primary services; customer base; organizational structure. Information Security Program: security policy; designated security officer; training frequency; incident response procedures; business continuity plan. Access Controls: authentication methods; multi-factor authentication use; privilege access management; role-based access control; access revocation procedures. Encryption: encryption standards used; encryption-in-transit; encryption-at-rest; key management procedures; encryption algorithm compliance. Data Handling: data classification procedures; handling procedures per classification; retention policies; secure disposal procedures; access logging. System Monitoring: intrusion detection systems; malware protection; vulnerability scanning frequency; patch management procedures; security monitoring tools. Incident Response: incident definition; detection procedures; response procedures; notification procedures; forensic investigation; regulatory notification. Business Continuity and Disaster Recovery: critical function identification; recovery time objectives; recovery point objectives; backup procedures; testing frequency; alternative site availability. Third-Party Management: sub-vendor identification; risk assessment of sub-vendors; contractual requirements; monitoring and audit. Certifications and Audits: SOC 2 certification status; ISO 27001 certification; other relevant certifications; audit frequency; audit rights for institutions. Risk Tiering Decision: Tier 1 (Low Risk) - Limited customer data, non-sensitive, strong controls, established vendor, no breach history, can rely on standard contract terms and periodic review. Tier 2 (Medium Risk) - Moderate data access, some sensitive data, good controls, established vendor, can use standard oversight with annual certification or review. Tier 3 (High Risk) - Extensive customer data access, sensitive data (SSN, account numbers), critical functions or high-risk environment, require annual audit, detailed contract requirements, heightened monitoring. Tier 4 (Critical) - Essential vendor, critical functions, extensive data access, highest sensitivity, require pre-engagement audit, detailed contract with extensive GLBA requirements, quarterly monitoring, right to audit anytime, dedicated relationship manager. Initial Assessment Documentation: create vendor file with assessment summary; store assessment questionnaire responses; maintain scoring documentation; record risk tier decision; document management approval; establish contract file with all vendor agreements. Reassessment Schedule: annual assessment for Tier 3 and 4 vendors; biennial for Tier 2; triennial for Tier 1; additional assessment if significant changes occur; changes warranting reassessment: change in ownership, merger or acquisition, significant service expansion, reported security incidents, examination findings, materially increased data access. Update Procedures: when vendor information changes; when control environment changes; when services expand or contract; when incidents occur; document changes and update risk tier if necessary. Examination Focus: examiners assess vendor assessment program: do assessments exist for all vendors; are assessments adequate; is documentation complete; are risk tiers appropriately assigned; are contractual requirements GLBA-compliant; is monitoring adequate per risk tier. Common Examination Findings: no documented vendor assessment for some vendors; inadequate security questionnaire; cursory risk assessment; no risk tiering; weak contracts missing GLBA requirements; inadequate monitoring and oversight; no reassessment process; no documentation retention.

definition: Ongoing monitoring and oversight of service providers to verify continued GLBA compliance
applicable_to: and incident prevention. Includes annual certifications
key_features: Per GLBA Safeguards Rule and Interagency Guidance on Third-Party Relationships, institutions must monitor service providers throughout the relationship to ensure continued compliance. Monitoring is continuous process; not one-time assessment; intensity depends on vendor risk tier. Monitoring components: annual vendor certification; periodic testing of controls; review of incident history; regulatory examination findings; renewal of security questionnaire; third-party audits (SOC 2, ISO 27001); on-site assessments for critical vendors; escalation procedures if issues identified. Vendor certification process: annual requirement; vendor management attests to compliance; signed by authorized vendor representative; documents data handling practices, safeguard maintenance, incident prevention, subcontractor management, regulatory changes, employee turnover. Monitoring activities: annual security questionnaire update; review of vendor business continuity and disaster recovery testing; incident tracking and review; performance metrics review; regulatory examination findings; new certifications obtained; contract modification; employee changes; service expansion. Documentation: maintain vendor monitoring file; record all monitoring activities; assessment results; certification status; incidents reported; remediation of issues; communication with vendor. Frequency: Tier 1 vendors annual certification minimum; Tier 2 vendors annual certification; Tier 3 vendors annual audit or certification plus semi-annual review; Tier 4 vendors quarterly monitoring, annual third-party audit, anytime audit rights.
column11: All vendors with ongoing customer information access; applies to duration of relationship; intensity depends on vendor risk tier; all institution sizes
column12: Vendor Manager for day-to-day monitoring; Compliance for certification review; IT Security for technical monitoring; Internal Audit for audit procedures; Risk Management for incident and escalation tracking
column13: GLBA Safeguards Rule Section 314; Interagency Guidance on Third-Party Relationships (2013 guidance on ongoing monitoring); Examination procedures for vendor monitoring; Banking regulator expectations for vendor oversight; OCC Bulletin on Third-Party Relationships

column15: Monitoring Procedures: Annual Vendor Certification process: vendor completes attestation that safeguards are maintained, data handled per agreement, no significant incidents occurred, subcontractors properly managed, regulatory changes addressed, employee training completed. Certification signed by vendor CEO or CFO attesting to accuracy. Institution reviews certification; compares to prior year; identifies changes or concerns; follows up on issues; updates vendor file. Periodic Testing: for critical or high-risk vendors, conduct testing of controls; may include: access control testing to confirm access restrictions; encryption testing to verify protection; disaster recovery testing; incident response testing; business continuity testing. Testing may be internal or external (third-party); results documented and reviewed. Incident Tracking and Review: monitor vendors for reported breaches or incidents; maintain incident log per vendor; review frequency depends on tier; assess vendor response; evaluate impact to institution; regulatory notification if needed. Semi-Annual or Quarterly Review (for Tier 3 and 4): review vendor business developments; assess any regulatory issues; discuss performance; review incident history; assess any new risks; update risk assessment if needed; schedule audits if required. Third-Party Audit Review (for Tier 3 and 4): obtain SOC 2 or ISO 27001 audit reports; review findings; assess control environment; identify deficiencies; follow up on remediation; use for annual assessment. On-Site Assessment (for Tier 4 - Critical vendors): periodic on-site visits; observe controls; interview personnel; test systems; verify business continuity; assess readiness. Frequency: annually for critical vendors; as deemed necessary for other tiers. Escalation and Remediation Procedures: if monitoring identifies non-compliance, inadequate controls, or incidents; initiate escalation process: Step 1 - Initial Communication: contact vendor; discuss issue; request explanation; ask for remediation plan. Step 2 - Remediation Plan: require vendor to submit remediation plan with timeline; assess adequacy; may require third-party audit or on-site assessment; document agreement. Step 3 - Progress Monitoring: monitor remediation progress; track implementation; verify completion; test controls if appropriate. Step 4 - Escalation if Necessary: if vendor unresponsive or remediation inadequate; escalate to vendor senior management; document communications; risk assessment update; may initiate contract termination or transition planning. Step 5 - Contract Termination: if vendor unable or unwilling to remediate; initiate contract termination; plan transition to new vendor; ensure secure data return; finalize data destruction if applicable; legal review of termination terms. Documentation Requirements: maintain vendor monitoring file with: annual certifications; audit reports; incident logs; remediation tracking; communication records; assessment updates; monitoring activity logs. Retention: retain documentation per retention policy; minimum 2-3 years; longer if incidents or enforcement action; accessible for examination. Performance Metrics: monitor vendor performance: availability/uptime percentage; incident frequency; response time to issues; compliance with service level agreements; customer satisfaction; regulatory compliance status. Incident Response by Vendor: when vendor experiences security incident; ensure vendor notifies institution immediately; assess impact to institution; determine if customer notification required; regulatory notification requirements; documentation of incident and response. Subcontractor Management: vendor responsible for their own subcontractors; institution should understand vendor's subcontractor oversight; require vendor to implement due diligence and monitoring; reserve right to audit subcontractors if needed; ensure vendor maintains control over subcontractors; require contractual safeguards in subcontractor agreements. Regulatory Change Management: monitor regulatory changes affecting vendor; ensure vendor implements required changes; verify compliance with new requirements; update contracts if necessary. Employee Turnover: vendor personnel turnover; high turnover may indicate problems; vendor should maintain training and institutional knowledge; assess impact of key personnel departures. Service Expansion: if vendor expands services or data access; reassess risk; update contracts; may require additional safeguards; verify capability to manage expanded scope. Examination Preparation: maintain organized vendor monitoring files; be able to demonstrate annual monitoring; evidence of incident detection and response; evidence of vendor remediation; assessment of vendor capability to maintain safeguards; documentation of escalation if needed.

node_name: Vendor Contract and Service Level Agreement
definition: Contractual requirements for service providers including GLBA compliance obligations
status: and service level agreements. Contract template includes all GLBA-required terms.
key_features: Per GLBA Safeguards Rule and guidance on third-party relationships, institution contracts with service providers must include specific GLBA compliance requirements. Service provider agreement establishes rights and obligations; protects institution; ensures vendor compliance. Required contract terms: safeguard requirements (maintain safeguards per GLBA); data handling (only for specified purposes, secure handling); sub-vendor management (vendor responsible for their vendors); incident notification (30-day notification requirement); access controls (appropriate access restrictions); encryption (required standards); business continuity (recovery time objectives); backup and recovery (procedures); audit rights (institution right to audit); termination (data return or destruction); liability and indemnification; insurance requirements; regulatory compliance attestations. Service level agreements (SLAs) establish performance expectations: availability/uptime percentage (typically 99.5% or higher); incident response time; recovery time objective; backup frequency; testing requirements; communication requirements; escalation procedures.
column11: All third-party service providers with customer information access; mandatory for compliance; applies to all vendor types; smaller vendors and large vendors; cloud providers, IT vendors, payroll, backup, disaster recovery, business intelligence, marketing
column12: General Counsel for contract drafting and negotiation; Compliance for GLBA requirements; Risk Management for terms and conditions; IT Security for technical safeguard requirements; Procurement for vendor selection and negotiation
column13: GLBA Safeguards Rule Section 314; Interagency Guidance on Third-Party Relationships (2013 guidance on contractual requirements); Sample contracts from regulators; Banking regulator expectations for vendor contracts; State law contract requirements
column14: Mandatory control; contract required before vendor engagement; contract quality directly affects institution liability; poor contracts result in enforcement findings; subject to examination review; contract compliance monitored throughout relationship
column15: Required Contract Provisions: GLBA Compliance: Service provider acknowledges GLBA requirements; agrees to comply with GLBA Privacy Rule and Safeguards Rule; commits to maintaining appropriate safeguards; agrees to notify institution of any non-compliance; implements security program consistent with GLBA standards. Data Handling: service provider will access customer information only for specified purposes outlined in contract; will not use data for vendor's other purposes without explicit authorization; will handle data securely per GLBA standards; will classify data per sensitivity; will implement appropriate access controls; will maintain audit logs of access. Safeguard Requirements: institution specifies minimum safeguards vendor must maintain; may reference GLBA requirements or specific standards (NIST, CIS, etc.); vendor commits to implement specified safeguards; includes administrative, technical, and physical safeguards; covers encryption standards; access control requirements; incident response procedures; business continuity; employee training. Sub-Vendor Management: service provider responsible for ensuring any sub-vendors they engage maintain same safeguards; service provider must obtain written agreements from sub-vendors with same GLBA requirements; institution may reserve right to audit sub-vendors; service provider must provide list of sub-vendors; must notify institution of sub-vendor changes; remains liable for sub-vendor compliance. Incident Notification: service provider must notify institution within 30 days of discovery of any incident involving customer information; includes any unauthorized access, theft, loss, or compromise; description of incident; number of customers affected; types of data involved; vendor response; recommendations for customer notification; institutions may require faster notification. Access Controls: service provider will implement appropriate access controls; limit access to customer information to authorized personnel only; implement role-based access control; require strong authentication; implement multi-factor authentication for privileged access; remove access upon employee termination. Encryption: service provider will encrypt customer information in transit (in-transit encryption); encrypt at rest (at-rest encryption); use encryption standards specified by institution or GLBA standards; implement secure key management; will not store encryption keys with encrypted data. Backup and Recovery: service provider will maintain secure backups of customer information; test recovery procedures regularly; maintain recovery time objectives specified in SLA; maintain recovery point objectives; ensure backup data is protected with same safeguards as primary data; document backup procedures. Business Continuity and Disaster Recovery: service provider will maintain business continuity plan; maintain disaster recovery procedures; test recovery quarterly or semi-annually; identify critical functions; establish recovery time and point objectives; maintain alternative processing sites; provide plan to institution; maintain capability to recover and restore data. Audit Rights: institution reserves right to audit service provider; right to conduct on-site examinations; right to request documentation; right to interview personnel; right to conduct security assessments; may request audit at any time; vendor agrees to cooperate with audits; third-party audit rights; access to SOC 2 or ISO 27001 reports. Termination and Data Handling: upon contract termination, service provider will return all customer information to institution; will destroy customer information per institution direction; will certify destruction; for cloud services, will ensure data is securely destroyed; will provide evidence of destruction; service provider will comply within specified timeframe (typically 30 days). Liability and Indemnification: service provider indemnifies institution for breach of contract; assumes liability for vendor's negligence or breach; institution liability limitation if breach of vendor's safeguard obligations; vendor maintains cyber liability insurance; institution named as additional insured. Insurance Requirements: vendor maintains cyber liability insurance minimum specified amount (typically $1-5 million depending on data access); errors and omissions insurance; professional liability; general liability; institution named as additional insured. Regulatory Compliance Attestations: service provider attests to GLBA compliance; certifies safeguards in place; confirms no regulatory violations; certifies no prior breaches affecting customer information. Service Level Agreement Terms: Availability: vendor guarantees uptime percentage (typically 99.5%); excludes scheduled maintenance; excludes events beyond vendor control; excludes institution-side failures; measured monthly or quarterly. Incident Response: vendor commits to respond to security incidents within specified timeframe; provide regular updates; assist with investigation and remediation; cooperate with law enforcement if applicable. Recovery Time Objective (RTO): maximum time to restore service after disruption; varies by service criticality; typical RTO 1 hour to 24 hours depending on service. Recovery Point Objective (RPO): maximum acceptable data loss; measured in time (e.g., maximum 1 hour of data loss); requires backup frequency to support RPO. Backup Requirements: backup frequency (daily, multiple times daily); backup testing (monthly, quarterly); backup retention period; backup storage location; backup security. Maintenance Windows: scheduled maintenance times; notification requirement (typically 48 hours advance); frequency and duration acceptable to institution. Communication and Escalation: vendor provides 24/7 support contact; escalation procedures for critical issues; communication methods (phone, email, ticketing); response time commitments per severity. Performance Reporting: vendor provides monthly or quarterly reports; uptime statistics; incident history; performance metrics; trend analysis. SLA Penalties: consequences for SLA violations; service credits; refund of fees; contract termination right if repeated violations. Contract Negotiation: institution and vendor negotiate contract terms; balance risk allocation; reasonableness of requirements; vendor capability to meet requirements; cost-benefit analysis; legal review by both parties; final approval by institution management and vendor; documented execution. Contract Renewal: contracts reviewed at renewal; terms updated if needed; requirements modified based on experience; performance assessment; continued vendor suitability; renegotiation of fees; updated safeguard requirements if applicable. Documentation: maintain contract file with executed agreement; all amendments; side letters; SLA; incident logs; performance reports; correspondence; vendor contact information; sensitive data: stored securely; access limited to appropriate personnel.
